title: What are some reasons not to vote for Joe Biden in 2020? - Quora

response.answer_text: Edit: This answer was for the Democratic Primary. I wrote it back in February, but now that I edited it, it’ll show it’s been updated to August 2020. I don’t think this question is the original one. I usually don’t put the questions at the top of my answers. Maybe I should start doing that. This answer is basically useless at this point. The primary is over. A2A. As I explained elsewhere, I think Biden’s name is tied to lots of bad policy that most Americans aren’t aware of.[1] Here’s some of it: Biden’s tried to cut Social security 3 times.He really stuck it to credit card holders with high fees, high interest, and debt that couldn't be discharged in bankruptcy. (Hillary supported it too)He stuck it to students who can’t discharge their student-loan debt in bankruptcy. (Hillary supported it too)He sponsored the 1994 crime bill that incarcerated so many people, and disproportionately incarcerated minorities. (Hillary supported it too)He tried to cut veterans benefits.He voted for the Wall Street bailouts. (Hillary supported it too)He voted against the auto bailouts. (I think Hillary made the right call on this one)He made the deal with Mitch McConnell that made the Bush tax cuts permanent.He was an enthusiastic supporter of NAFTA. (Hillary supported it too)He was enthusiastic supporter of the Iraq War. (Hillary supported it too)I don’t like to replay 2016, but I think we must to understand why Biden might be a bad candidate. Both Hillary and Trump had historically high disapproval ratings. Both suppressed voter turnout, but Hillary suppressed too many votes in the wrong states like Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania. She suppressed Black, Latino and the youth vote,[2] and some working class whites who voted for Obama twice flipped to Trump.[3] Let’s look at the points above to see how they’ll play with these voters. If you’re struggling in this economy, like some workers and young people of all colors, 2, 6, 7, 8, and 9, are all bad. Point 3 is bad for struggling students. Point 4 is bad for Hispanics and Blacks. Point 1 usually doesn’t play well with anyone but the rich. Point 5 won’t help with veterans. Point 10 hurt Hillary; I don’t see why it wouldn't hurt Biden. It might be worse for Biden because as chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, he pushed hard to give George W Bush the go ahead to invade Iraq. I just see too many policy parallels between Biden’s and Hillary’s records, although Biden’s is a bit worse. As I said in another post,[4] Biden keeps insulting millennials, immigration activists, climate activists, and some older people. You know, the people whose votes he’ll need. Sometimes he tells people to go vote for Trump, and maybe that’s what they’ll do. Many in the media dismiss all of this by saying things like Well, that’s just Biden. His gaffes are endearing. Really? Then why were his 1988 and 2008 presidential campaigns both disasters, Obama didn’t pick Biden to appeal to Black voters. Obama had that covered. He chose Biden to appeal to white voters in a few states. And why hasn’t Obama endorsed his own VP? Recently, it was found that Obama opined The world would be better off if every country was run by women and old men got out of the way.[5] And Obama’s allegedly working behind the scenes to help Warren.[6] This all sounds like the opposite of an endorsement. This might sound obvious, but I’m not sure it’s obvious to Biden. In politics, you’re supposed to make people like you. You’re supposed to offer people policy they like and it would be great if you could point to your past policy as something that’s already helped them. I realize the media’s pushing Biden hard, but the same media was pushing Hillary hard in 2016. And I really think there are some legitimate questions about Biden’s mental abilities. If you compare his debates with Sarah Palin and Paul Ryan with the most recent Democratic debates, he just sounds likes he’s lost some cognitive ability. He's lost his train of thought in mid-sentence a number of times and he blurts out nonsense like: We bring social workers into homes and parents to help them deal with how to raise their children. It's not want they don't want to help. They don't — they don't know quite what to do. Play the radio, make sure the television — excuse me, make sure you have the record player on at night, the, the — make sure that kids hear words. A kid coming from a very poor school, a very poor background will hear 4 million words fewer spoken by the time they get there. If this makes sense to you, please tell me what he was trying to say.
